name: Domain, Alias, CNAME, SSL in EFS
title: Domain, Alias, CNAME, SSL in EFS
body:
Overview

This article provides comprehensive information about domains, aliases, CNAMEs, and SSL certificates in the context of Tivian's customer installations. It covers general information, FAQs, available options, and processes for setting up custom domains and SSL certificates.

Information

This guide focuses on the technical aspects of domain management, SSL implementation, and alias configuration for Tivian's customer installations. It provides essential information for support staff and technical contacts.

    • General Information
    • Tivian's Domain Offerings
    • Tivian's SSL Offerings
    • Customer-provided SSL certificates
    • Processing a Custom Domain Request (TBR WITH TIVIAN)

General Information

Every installation has a technical domain (e.g., ab1234.customervoice360.com) with some exceptions for old installations. This generic domain is created automatically and cannot be manipulated. It always includes SSL and is provided at no extra cost to the customer.

Tivian's Domain Offerings

  • Custom domain from .customervoice360.com (e.g., bounty.customervoice360.com) with SSL included. Customer pays for this option.
  • Second-Level-Domain or sub-domain, which can be from the customer or Tivian.
    • All domains now include SSL, automatically provisioned from Tivian
    • Customer pays for this option.
    • Support does NOT actively ask the customer for it.

CNAME Information

  • To find out who manages a domain, use http://whois.domaintools.com/. If you see NS1.OPST.DE or NS2.OPST.DE, it's likely managed by Tivian.
  • DNS propagation can be checked using: https://www.whatsmydns.net/.
  • Extensive DNS information can be found in The world of DNS, Email + Certificates and how it relates to EFS(-Aliases).

Tivian's SSL Offerings

The provider we use to get SSL is Let's Encrypt and the certificates are automatically exchanged every 3 months. The customer does not need to inform us that the certificate needs to be exchanged.

There are four main scenarios when a customer requests an Alias, detailed below.

From a cost perspective, the first scenario is the least expensive one for Tivian, however, the last scenario is preferred, as it allows full ownership, and requiring the least customer communication.

Customer owns the domain, manages DNS, Tivian handles SSL

  1. Tivian actions
    1. Configure alias on our site
    2. Set up SSL. 
    3. Set up monitoring for the domain and SSL of our site (If the customer's DNS no longer points to EFS, monitoring will start on our site and the customer will be informed. If there are any problems with SSL, these will be resolved by Tivian)
  2. Customer actions
    1. Adjustment of all DNS entries (CNAME, NS, etc.)

Customer owns the domain, manages DNS, provides SSL to Tivian

  1. Tivian actions
    1. Configure alias on our site
    2. Setting up SSL provided by the customer (before the certificate expires, the customer will be informed in advance of when he must send us a new certificate)
    3. Set up monitoring on our side (If the customer's DNS no longer points to EFS, monitoring starts on our side and the customer is informed. If there are problems with SSL, the customer may be contacted, for example to issue a new certificate)
  2. Customer actions
    1. Adjustment of all DNS entries (CNAME, NS, etc.)
    2. Provision of SSL certificate (customer must ensure that all certificates are provided in the correct format)

Customer owns the domain, transfers complete management to Tivian

  1. Tivian actions
    1. Configure alias on our site
    2. Set up monitoring on our site
    3. Set up SSL (Let's Encrypt)
  2. Customer actions
    1. Adjustment of the name server (Tivian NS must be stored) DNS entries so that Tivian can manage the domain.
    2. Alternatively, we can take over the domain completely and for this we need the auth code for the domain transfer.

Tivian registers and manages a new domain for the customer

The desired “alias domain” is still available for registration and Tivian will obtain it and take over the complete administration.

  1. Tivian actions
    1. Register domain
    2. Configure alias on our site
    3. Set up monitoring on our site
    4. Set up SSL (Let's Encrypt)
  2. Todos for customer
    1. NONE

Customer-provided SSL certificates

If a customer insists on using their own SSL certificate (not recommended), follow this workflow:

CSR from Tivian

Request the following data from the customer for CSR (Certificate Signing Request):

C=DE (Two Letter Country Code like US,DE,GB) 
ST=Hessen (Province/Country/State) 
L=Frankfurt am Main (City) 
O=Customer XYZ (Business Name) 
OU=IT (Department Name) 
CN= The fully qualified domain name of the domain, that shall be secured like www.3uu.de

After the CSR is generated, it is supplied for the customer, who has to provide us with the SSL certificate, in the format found in the next section.

No CSR from Tivian

If the customer generates the CSR, they can also generate the certificate by themselves. The customer must provide Tivian with the certificate in the following format:

  • Format: ApacheModSSL
  • Files: CA + CRT (unencrypted)
  • Key (encrypted)
  • Type: x509 PEM

Processing a Custom Domain Request (TBR WITH TIVIAN)

Sales has to create an Opportunity in Salesforce.
Support needs a technical contact person from customer.

 

Once you receive the requested information from the customer, please engage the Infrastructure (SaaS) Team.

FAQ

What is SSL?

SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) is a protocol that ensures encrypted data transmission over the Internet.

How do I know if a domain already has SSL?

Enter the domain with https:// in your browser's address bar. If there's no error message and you see a green lock next to the URL, the domain has SSL.

What is an Alias?

An alias is a second domain name for an existing website. For example, if the generic domain is ab1234.customervoice360.com, an alias could be i-love-kitkat.com. The alias points to the generic domain, displaying the same page.

What is a "custom URL Alias managed by Tivian"?

This likely refers to sub-domains of a customer's main domain (e.g., www.kundendomain.de, umfrage.kundendomain.de) managed by Tivian. These should be treated as separate aliases due to potential for unlimited sub-domains.

What are the costs associated with different scenarios?

Costs vary depending on the scenario, including domain registration, renewal, SSL certificates, and additional setup processes. Scenario 1 incurs the least costs, while Scenario 4 is preferred by Tivian for maximum control and minimal customer communication.
